ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Just wish to point out that the TA for this course was absolutely not up to the task. The only interaction we had with her was during a Review Session which was not helpful at all. She actually doesn't even know who is enrolled in the class or not (there are just 7 of us) or how to write our names.
It would be helpful on occasion to have a few extra visuals, especially for the spelling of some of the mores obscure technical terms.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Large array of issues, and the main topics were very well chosen (nutrients, roots, photosynthesis, water and stress).

The final project gave me an opportunity to explore my own interests. Listening to my classmates' final presentations was wonderful because their topics were so varied and interesting. I also liked the format of the exams because I feel it gave me the opportunity to synthesize what I learned in the class.
Graeme knows an astonishing amount about plant structure and function.
Lecture notes are mostly based on research studies from past to date. Student presentation on papers were interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Graeme's knowledge on the subject is essentially limitless, including all topics of plant physiology qnd past and present experiments. But it has been frustrating at times because the way the material is communicated to us makes it really hard to know what's relevant. Maybe making it more focused on forestry-specific issues would help. An active TA would also be a plus.
Sometimes I felt lost in the details without understanding how the super technical information fit into the broader picture.
It can be hard to stay focused in the class when the professor is flipping through transparencies and the student can't follow his train of thought.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: A basic understand of plant physiology should be required for every Master of Forestry graduate.

I think it was helpful to take this class to better understand how silvicultural prescriptions can ameliorate stress on trees. I think having this basis will help me be a better, more thoughtful manager.
It serves as the basis for my thesis research

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See answer above.
It was an important addition to my MF program
I needed a plant biology course.
Need to understand physiological process that pertains to forest function

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: To some extent, but then again I would have learned more if the teaching style was a bit different.
Yes
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure that you keep yourself on tract, and focus on the issues that you want to learn.
Take notes on paper; it's easy to let your attention wander with a laptop.
I recommend this for students interested in forestry, ecology and agriculture and related disciplines.
